I'm glad you are looking at what is meant by austerity. It is not simply consuming less. It is consuming less relative to what we produce. Any cut in consumption (government spending) that results in a corresponding drop in production is futile. The trick is to find ways to maintain production while consuming less. Government spending on infrastructure improvements is one such way since you are shifting consumption to the future as our future population benefits.
This is an austerity we should all be able to back, and it is an argument than can be more productive than saying austerity might intuitively seem right but it works in reverse. The argument should not be about whether austerity works or not, but rather what is (or should be) meant by austerity.

The government and social workers in Japan have long been concerned about the fact that reported suicides in the country have regularly exceeded 30,000 persons a year. The general feeling seems to be that the most important cause is shrinking economic opportunities for middle class male workers rather than, say, a cultural attraction to "seppuku" (ritual suicide). Even in large urban areas, Japanese tend to live in highly disciplined, group-oriented and obligation-heavy social environments, which apparently cause them as much psychic pain as the individualism and social isolation that afflicts Americans.

Perhaps in both societies, there has not (only) been a decline in social contact, but a decrease in warm or empathetic relations among people, which might be a consequence of a hyper-capitalistic society. People are made to feel inadequate because they are not as successful as many other people, and have no one to turn to to unburden their hearts. So the core issue is not so much social obligations (of which the Japanese in general have many) versus ("American-style") social isolationism, as the sterility of social contacts.

Perhaps we need to educate young people more to understand the importance of good human relationships and act in positive, non-pragmatic ways to enhance them. We also need to create a slower, more sharing and less competitive society where life is worth living . . . for everyone.

Who crushed Germany in World War II?

An excellent study is Richard Overy, Why the Allies Won.

Overy reports, surprisingly, that the Soviet Union vastly outproduced Germany in war materiel during World War II. The notorious and epic inefficiencies of the Soviet economy came later; during WWII the Soviet's communist economy outperformed the less statist, more capitalist German economy by a wide margin.

Soviet armies, in turn, carried the main burden of defeating the Germans. So the allied victory in World War II is partly a story of successful capitalist production in the U.S.; but, even moreso, a story of successful communist production in the USSR.

I hate giving the Soviets, or communism, credit for anything. They give new meaning to the term "evil." On the other had, Timothy is so annoying that he can provoke even me to saying a nice word for the Soviet economic system.

As the great sociologist Daniel Bell once wrote:

"As to the 'acceleration' of the pace of change, the phrase has no precise meaning: a pace requires a 'metric', and we have no such measurements of change. An individual born in 1800 and living to 1860 would have seen factories, railroads, steamships, a change from rural to urban life; from 1860 to 1920, the introduction of electricity and the telephone; from 1920 to 1980, the automobile, aeroplane and television, with the reduction of travel time and the banding of the world into one global village. Is the 'future shock' of recent decades any greater than for people who lived through those earlier periods, or is it only a mirage?"

(Times Literary Supplement, June 9, 1995)

If hardship stories sell, then everyone will find one to tell. That is one reason there are so many of them.

Another reason is that they reinforce our individualistic competitive ideology, in which each person creates his or her own success, triumphing over adversity. Paul Ryan's father died and he was then eligible for help from government programs. He uses his story to illustrate the value of perseverance, not the value of government help.

The stars in "Dancing with the Stars" must win battles with their own bodies to succeed, but they must also bond with and accept help and instruction from their professional dancer partners.

The triumph over adversity usually occurs with help; many times the help is central. But our ideology downplays that help and teaches us not to see it and to think it is an expensive luxury or even a hindrance that should be done away with.

Since it's late in the day, I'll drop the other shoe and name the character I had in mind. Perry Mason's phone number was (usually) MAdison 5-1190, but other numbers were used inconsistently at times.

suejean, I don't know whether the TV scripts described him as "scooping" up the phone, since it's just a visual action on film and the audience can characterize it with any verb they like. I guess that's why it doesn't bother me. He just answers the phone, in whatever mood he's in at the moment.

But early on in the series, at least once, and I think twice (maybe more), the phone rings and Perry, who is nearer to it, wordlessly hands over the receiver to Della to answer for him. (Maybe there's a legal or logistical reason for that, but it seems more like, "I'm the boss, you're the secretary, you answer it.") In later episodes he seems more willing to answer it himself. It seems a little bratty and patronizing when he has Della do it, and a little jarring when viewed in these more "enlightened" times.

Alan, I'm willing to cut Perry some slack. In the days before caller I.D., that was the only way to allow a signal "Tell them I'm not in!".
